title: Hanlon's Razor
description: Never attribute to malice that which is adequately explained by stupidity. This principle suggests that when something goes wrong, we should not assume malicious intent if it can be explained by incompetence or error.
example1: Misplacing keys and assuming theft when you might have just forgotten where you put them.
example2: A project failure due to team errors rather than intentional sabotage.

title: Inversion Thinking
description: Approach problems by thinking about what you don't want to happen. This problem-solving technique involves thinking in reverseâ€”considering undesirable outcomes to identify how to prevent them or what the best path forward might be.
example1: Determining how to ruin a product launch in order to avoid those pitfalls.
example2: Asking 'What would cause this to fail?' to find risk factors.

title: Parkinson's Law
description: Work expands so as to fill the time available for its completion. This law observes that the amount of work demanded will increase to use up all the time allocated for it.
example1: A project taking all 2 weeks even if it could've been completed faster.
example2: A task expanding in scope because there is ample time available for it.

title: The Dunning-Kruger Effect
description: People with low competence tend to overestimate their abilities. This cognitive bias describes how individuals with limited knowledge or skill in a specific area tend to believe they are more competent than they actually are.
example1: Someone new to programming believing they're an expert.
example2: A novice driver thinking they are better than experienced drivers.

title: Occam's Razor
description: When comparing hypotheses, the one with the fewest assumptions should be selected. This principle advocates for simplicity, suggesting that the simplest explanation, often with the least assumptions, is usually the correct one.
example1: Diagnosing a car issue first with common problems before considering complex ones.
example2: In science, preferring a simpler theory until more evidence necessitates complexity.

title: Loss Aversion
description: The pain of a loss is psychologically more powerful than the pleasure of an equivalent gain. This cognitive bias means people feel the pain of a loss more strongly than the joy of an equivalent gain, leading to risk-averse behavior.
example1: Being more upset about losing $50 than happy about finding $50.
example2: Holding onto losing investments longer than rational because selling feels like a loss.

title: Availability Heuristic
description: We tend to overestimate the likelihood of events that are easily recalled or vivid in our memory. This mental shortcut involves relying on readily available examples when making judgments or decisions, which can distort our understanding of frequency.
example1: Overestimating the likelihood of a plane crash after seeing news coverage of one.
example2: Thinking shark attacks are more common than they are due to media portrayal.

title: The Law of Diminishing Marginal Utility
description: The satisfaction or benefit derived from each additional unit of a good decreases as consumption increases. This law suggests that the more of a good or service you consume, the less satisfaction or utility you gain from each additional unit.
example1: The first slice of pizza being more satisfying than the tenth.
example2: The first hour of extra practice being more beneficial than the tenth hour.

title: Feedback Loops
description: The output of a system can be fed back into the system as an input, creating either a reinforcing or balancing effect. These loops demonstrate how the output of a system can influence its subsequent operation through feedback mechanisms, creating either positive or negative reinforcement.
example1: Positive feedback in climate change leading to more warming.
example2: Negative feedback in a thermostat maintaining a stable temperature.

title: The Halo Effect
description: One positive trait we see in a person or product influences our view of their other traits. This cognitive bias leads us to judge an individual's or entity's overall character based on a single positive attribute.
example1: Assuming an attractive person is also intelligent and kind.
example2: Thinking a brand is high quality based on one successful product.

title: Mental Accounting
description: People treat money differently based on where it came from or what it's for. This behavioral economics concept shows how people separate money into different mental categories, leading to different spending and saving behaviors.
example1: Spending a tax refund more easily than money from regular earnings.
example2: Having a 'vacation fund' and a 'bill paying fund' with different spending attitudes.

title: Second-Order Thinking
description: Consider not just the direct consequences of an action, but also the indirect and longer-term effects. This type of thinking involves exploring implications beyond the immediate, anticipating downstream consequences of decisions and actions.
example1: Evaluating a policy not just by its initial purpose, but by its long term impacts.
example2: Analyzing a business strategy not just by initial gains, but by its indirect effects.

title: The Backfire Effect
description: When our beliefs are challenged, it can cause us to double down on the original belief. This bias occurs when evidence presented against a belief actually strengthens a person's adherence to it.
example1: Doubling down on a conspiracy theory after being presented with contrary evidence.
example2: Ignoring facts about a political candidate and remaining resolute in your support.

title: The Base Rate Fallacy
description: We tend to ignore general statistical information when evaluating a specific event. This fallacy describes the tendency to disregard relevant statistical base rates when presented with specific information.
example1: Ignoring general health risks when hearing about a specific disease case.
example2: Overestimating a job candidate's chances of success despite a low success rate for such hires.

title: System 1 and System 2 Thinking
description: Our brains use two different types of thinking: fast, automatic (System 1) and slow, deliberate (System 2). This model describes how our brains operate using fast and intuitive thinking (System 1) and slower, more analytical thinking (System 2).
example1: Making a quick decision based on intuition (System 1) versus carefully calculating pros and cons (System 2).
example2: Reacting instinctively to danger versus thinking through the best strategy in a situation.

title: Chameleon Effect
description: We unconsciously mimic the behaviors of those around us, especially when trying to build rapport. This phenomenon involves unintentionally mirroring the postures, mannerisms, and facial expressions of others to improve social interactions.
example1: Adopting the same speaking style as someone you're trying to impress.
example2: Unknowingly mirroring the body language of a conversational partner.

title: First Principles Reasoning
description: Break complex problems into foundational elements and use these elements to build your reasoning. A first principle is a foundational assumption or proposition that cannot be derived from other assumptions or propositions. By breaking down problems into first principles and re-constructing solutions, you're less likely to be biased.
example1: A child repeatedly asking "why?" to answers for an initial question.
example2: A company building a cheaper product by using raw materials firsthand instead of following conventions.

title: Proximate and Root Causes
description: Discovering the root cause of an event involves looking deeper than the immediate causes for that event. This model emphasizes the importance of identifying the fundamental reasons behind an issue rather than just addressing the surface problems.
example1: Investigating a machine failure not just by fixing the broken part but understanding why it broke.
example2: Analyzing poor sales not just by adjusting prices but understanding market behavior.

title: Social Proof
description: We tend to copy the behavior of others, especially during times of uncertainty. This concept explains how people often look to others' actions to guide their own, particularly in uncertain situations.
example1: Choosing a crowded restaurant over an empty one believing it must be better.
example2: Following fashion trends because others are doing the same.

title: Survivorship Bias
description: We tend to focus on things that survived and overlook things that didn't. This can lead to overly optimistic beliefs. This bias involves concentrating on the people or things that made it past some selection process and overlooking those that did not, often leading to an inaccurate understanding of reality.
example1: Believing that all startups succeed because you only hear about the successful ones.
example2: Assuming that a certain workout is effective because you see fit people doing it, not considering those who failed.

title: Reciprocity
description: We tend to feel obligated to repay positive actions towards us (e.g., favors, gifts) even if they are unwanted. This principle explains the human tendency to return a favor or good deed, creating a cycle of mutual benefit and cooperation.
example1: Feeling compelled to buy something after receiving a free sample.
example2: Returning a favor to a friend even if it was unsolicited.

title: Hindsight Bias
description: The feeling that we could have predicted an event after it occurs (i.e., we "knew it all along"). This bias involves the belief that after an event has occurred, it was predictable, despite there having been little or no objective basis for predicting it.
example1: Believing you knew the outcome of a game after it has ended.
example2: Thinking you saw signs of an economic crash only after it happens.

title: Confirmation Bias
description: We have a tendency to perceive things in a way that re-enforces or aligns with our preexisting beliefs. This bias leads us to favor information that confirms our existing beliefs and disregard evidence that contradicts them.
example1: Only reading news sources that align with your political views.
example2: Interpreting ambiguous information in a way that supports your existing opinions.

title: Scarcity
description: We tend to place higher value on things that are rare and lower value on things that are abundant. This principle explains how limited availability can increase the perceived value of an item.
example1: Buying limited edition products because they seem more valuable.
example2: Feeling more urgency to act when a deadline is near.

title: Pareto Principle
description: For many scenarios, 80% of the effects stem from 20% of the causes. This is often referred to as the 80/20 rule. This principle suggests that a small number of causes often lead to a large portion of the effects, which can help prioritize efforts.
example1: 20% of customers generating 80% of the revenue.
example2: 20% of the work leading to 80% of the results.

title: Thought Experiment
description: We can explore a theory by imagining an experiment for it and thinking through its potential consequences. This mental model involves using hypothetical scenarios to understand and explore ideas and theories.
example1: Imagining the consequences of a policy change before implementing it.
example2: Using hypothetical situations to teach complex concepts in education.

title: Diderot Effect
description: Obtaining something new can lead us to purchase additional, complementary things that we otherwise wouldn't have. This effect explains how acquiring a new possession can lead to a spiral of consumption, resulting in the acquisition of more items.
example1: Buying a new outfit and then feeling the need to buy matching accessories.
example2: Purchasing a new phone and then buying related gadgets.

title: Map and Territory Relation
description: While models are useful in explaining reality, they are not reality itself. This principle emphasizes the difference between models or representations and the actual reality they depict.
example1: Using a business model to understand a market but recognizing it doesn't capture all nuances.
example2: Understanding a map's limitations in representing the geographic terrain accurately.

title: Gambler's Fallacy
description: The mistaken belief that a random event is more or less likely to occur based on past outcomes. This fallacy involves thinking that future probabilities are altered by past events in a random process.
example1: Believing a coin flip is more likely to be heads after several tails in a row.
example2: Thinking a lottery number is "due" because it hasn't been drawn in a while.

title: Goodhart's Law
description: When a measure becomes a target, it ceases to be a good measure. This law indicates that when a metric is used as a target for policy or decision-making, it loses its effectiveness as a measure.
example1: Schools focusing on test scores to gauge performance but neglecting actual learning.
example2: Companies inflating sales numbers to meet targets without improving overall business health.

title: Sunk Cost Fallacy
description: We have a tendency to continue an endeavor after investing resources into it even if it's no longer worthwhile. This fallacy involves continuing an activity or project due to the invested resources (time, money, effort) rather than current and future costs and benefits.
example1: Continuing to hold onto a stock because of the amount invested despite its poor performance.
example2: Staying in a bad relationship because of the time already spent in it.

title: Diminishing Returns
description: In productive processes, the value gained from increasing one input but keeping others the same will at some point start decreasing. This principle explains how adding more of one factor of production, while holding others constant, will eventually yield lower per-unit returns.
example1: Adding more workers to a factory but seeing less productivity per worker after a certain point.
example2: Applying more fertilizer to a crop but seeing smaller increases in yield.

title: Recency Bias
description: We tend to place greater emphasis on recent events over past ones. This bias involves giving disproportionate weight to the most recent information or events, often at the expense of a longer-term perspective.
example1: Overreacting to recent stock market movements without considering long-term trends.
example2: Evaluating employee performance based on their most recent work rather than overall history.

title: Premack's Principle
description: More desirable behaviors can be used to reinforce less desirable behaviors. This principle suggests using the opportunity to engage in a preferred activity as a reward for performing a less preferred activity.
example1: Allowing a child to play video games only after doing their homework.
example2: Rewarding yourself with a treat after completing a workout.

title: Goldilocks Rule
description: Optimal motivation occurs when tasks are neither too hard nor too easy. This rule states that people are most motivated to work on tasks that are just right in terms of difficultyâ€”not too hard and not too easy.
example1: Managing a team's workload so tasks are challenging but achievable.
example2: Setting personal goals that are ambitious but realistic.

title: Illeism (Third Person Thinking)
description: Referring to oneself in the third person can create psychological distance and objectivity. This technique involves speaking about oneself in the third person to gain a more detached and objective perspective on one's own thoughts and feelings.
example1: An athlete using third person to self-motivate, e.g., "You can do this, [Name]!"
example2: A person reflecting on their actions by thinking, "What would [Name] do in this situation?"

title: Hyperbolic Discounting
description: People tend to choose smaller, immediate rewards over larger, later rewards. This bias involves preferring immediate rewards over future ones, even if the future rewards are significantly larger, due to the tendency to discount the value of later rewards.
example1: Choosing to spend money now rather than save for retirement.
example2: Opting for a small treat today instead of a bigger reward next week.

title: Lindy Effect
description: Things that have been around for a while are likely to continue to stick around. This principle suggests that the longer something has existed, the longer it's likely to continue to exist in the future.
example1: Trusting long-standing companies to remain in business.
example2: Believing that books or technologies that have lasted for decades will continue to be relevant.

title: Zeigarnik Effect
description: We tend to remember unfinished tasks better than completed ones. This effect explains why people often recall incomplete tasks or thoughts more easily than completed ones.
example1: Remembering to complete a task that you left unfinished the night before.
example2: Feeling a lingering need to complete a project that was interrupted.

title: Endowment Effect
description: We tend to value things we own higher than we would if we didn't own them. This bias involves ascribing higher value to items simply because we own them, compared to if we did not own them.
example1: Overpricing your house when selling because of personal attachment.
example2: Refusing to sell a stock at market price because you own it.
